discussion.content: By process of elimination, C the most logical answer.
unintentional DoS would not be scanning the device or the network, so I agree that C is the most logical response
C....but go with ya gut and get it wrong! lol

The smurf attack is a type of DoS attack, and this is clearly not the case. This is a case of a compromised system because it performs a network scan to get a view of the network, view services availables either for lateral movement or for privilage escalation.

The answer should be "A", for more explanation, check this.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smurf_attack

comments.content: Smurf Attack isn't on the exam objectives at all though
That source does not describe what is happening in the question at all, which means to me that the answer is 'C'
A smurf attack is a DDOS attack, not a network scan. If a host on your network is scanning other hosts and it's not a known scanner, it's comprimised.

questions.question_text: A network security technician observes multiple attempts to scan network hosts and devices. All the attempts originate from a single host on the network. Which of the following threats is MOST likely involved?
Which of the following would be the MOST efficient subnet mask for a point-to-point link?

discussion.content: It is /31 ! It works well ! just test it or google just a minute...
this would be b /29 because there are no available hosts on a /31 address because they would be taken up by the network and broadcast address

comments.content: Checked Neela's comment, and it says that you can, in fact, use /31 for point to point. Interesting
Wrong, you need a broadcast and net id, plus the point-to-point connection.
Agreed, just did the sub net calculations, answer is '/29'

discussion.content:
Guess I gotta update my lesson plan for next year! some info that helped me understand this better: Look up RFC 3021. 
Using 31-Bit Prefixes on IPv4 Point-to-Point Links https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3021
If you don't think it's /31, you need to study more jesus christ

if there was a choice 30 , i would take it b/c Again, the /30 subnet mask provides the most efficient use of IP addresses by not wasting any IP addresses when it is applies to a point to point network connection.so 31 is the best answer .
/31 is correct. On a point-to-point connection, you don't need a broadcast address or a network address. All you need is the IPs for the 2 hosts. /32 is for a single host. /31 is definitely correct.

rfc3021: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3021
"Using 31-Bit Prefixes on IPv4 Point-to-Point Links"

https://community.cisco.com/t5/switching/when-and-why-we-use-31-subnet/td-p/1642780#:~:text=Using%20a%20%2F31%20subnet%20mask%20helps%20conserve%20your,but%20are%20rapidly%20running%20out%20of%20address%20space.
I did some research and just found out that /31 is actually the correct answer, it works for point to point. Watch this video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sCivzbTkjQE

comments.content: I agree with this, /29 is wrong as there are 6 usable addresses leaving 4 left over. /30 would provide 2 addresses perfect for point-to-point.
/30 would provide 4 addresses and you only need 2 for a point to point connection. So /31 is the correct answer.

discussion.content: /29 is wrong. For broadcast and network /30 will work. /31 for point to point. /32 for dedicated connection
/31 is correct for Point to Point links because you dont need a network ID or a Broadcast address.
The answer is /31, it is a well known fact that /31 subnet is the most efficient for point to point connections!

RFC 3021 was introduced to allow the use of /31 subnets specifically for point-to-point links that don’t require a local broadcast. In these networks, any packet sent by one node must be intended for the other node, as there are no other possibilities
Although /29 sounds correct, I am pretty sure its /31
Some of you need extensive studies.. you can't use the final two bits. /31 and /32 are off limits.

comments.content: From what I've found everywhere online, the answer is /31.
Sorry buddy. RFC 3021 calls for /31 to be used for point to point links
For a point to point link you don't use or need a network or broadcast address. It's literally point to point; only two addresses needed here. /31 is the correct answer.

discussion.content: Since this is for a PPP connection a /31 is the best option. Look for RFC 3021 on Google
I’m guessing if you’re configuring a Boarder Router / WAN Link a /31 should work.

questions.question_text: A technician wants to prevent an unauthorized host from connecting to the network via Ethernet. Which of the following is a Layer 2 access control the technician should implement?

discussion.content: Port security enables you to electronically turn the switch port off so that connecting a cable will not even work unless enabled from the global config mode

comments.content: You are confusing port security with shutting down the port...

discussion.content: keyword "via Ethernet" aka port
Why not Access control lists?

comments.content: ACLs are not only on firewalls, but most commonly on firewalls. Also, ACLs can be up to Layer 7. They prevent/allow HTTP, POP, IMAP traffic.

They said layer 2 - layer 2 deals with mac address
Port Security is done via mac addresses

ACL's are done on a firewall - firewalls are layer 3

They want to prevent an unauthorized host from connecting to the network via Ethernet. Anyone can hook up their laptop to an open Ethernet port. Port Security (Layer 2) would only allow certain computers to connect via a given port. ACL is associated with Layer 3 of the OSI model. Therefore, answer is D.

If you look at the DNS Suffix you can see that one of the domains is guestwifi.local whilst the other one is comtia.net. Assuming that Guest Wifi is segmented from the rest of the corporate network, you wouldnt be able to access corporate resources on the guest wifi.

discussion.content: Anyone knows why it is B ?

questions.question_text: Ann, a network technician, has just installed a fiber switch in a datacenter. To run the fiber cabling, Ann plans the cable route over the top of the rack using the cable trays, down to the switch, coiling up any excess cable. As Ann configures the switch, she notices several messages in the logging buffer stating the receive signal of the SFP is too weak. Which of the following is MOST likely the cause of the errors in the logging buffer?

discussion.content: Obviously light will reflect upon too much bending of cable

comments.content: But if I *increase* a radius, the bend decreases...the circle gets bigger, so there's less bend per distance of cable...exceeding a bend radius means the circle got bigger, not smaller...or am I totally screwed up here?
